My dear Halford, Your Secret letter of September 27th and enclosure from de Gaury - B.I. Monopoly. I think the matter now perhaps 'merits Government intervention' on the strength of the enclosed letter from Messrs. Shaw Wallis, Calcutta dated October 7th, addressed to Messrs. Isbraddtsen Moller Company, Incorporated of New York, copy sent to Adnrew Weir and Company here. The facts are as follows About the 20th September the Manager of the Rafidain Oil Company in Basra, who had been trying for weeks to get passages to India for Anglo-Iranian Oil Company employees, heard that there was accommodation on a vessel of the Isbrandtsen Moller line for which Andrew Weir are agents. Murchison of Andrew Weir told Blackford of the Rafidain Oil Company he could not take passengers without consulting Gray Mackenzie, the B*I. agents, because of the conference arrangement for a monopoly of passenger traffic. He telephoned Gray Mackenzie’s manager who said he would telegraph the B. I. agents, Mackinnon ,;ackenzie in Bombay and sent a wire 'Andrew Weir wish to book passengers for India' adding that the B.I. was fully booked and asking if there was any objection. In due course he received a wire to the effect that Andrew Weir might arrange passages in the Isbrandtsen Moller &hip provided tickets were issued through Gray Mackenzie as is done in the case of passages by Silver Java line. This telegram only arrived after the ship had left and so was useless, and anyway in the meantime Andrew Weir had received instructions from Isbrandtsen Moller in New York not to take passengers. But note the wording of the enclosed letter It accuses Andrew Weir of soliciting passengers and not to their face but to a third party, thus putting them in a very bad light, a thing they have in no way deserved as it was only at the urgent request of Blackford that Murchison approached Gray Mackenzie. In fact he could not have been more straightforward about it. I asked Murchison to ask Gray Mackenzie’s agent for some explanation as I thought it would make less bad blood that way than if X did. The result was that, as detailed above, the latter denied ever having used the word soliciting, but tried to make out that this word had conveyed no different meaning from the text of his telegram 'Andrew Weir wish to book passengers' which savours to me of casuistry. He also speaking in front of Murchison to me down the telephone said 'Isbrandtsen Moller are well known pirates', an accusation which Murchison was at pains to correct to me immediately afterwards, pointing out that Isbrandtsen Moller ships are coming here under Ministry of Shipping charter to ship grain and are in no way interested in passengers. And anyway it was- 2 - PL was not Isbrandtsen Moller which was concerned in the particular incident, but Murchison himself, by way solely of trying to help the Anglo-Iranian and their stranded employees. So if any one was a 'pirate' it was Murchison and it was scarcely politjse of Gray Mackenzie to imply this in front of him, even if it was intended in a Pickwickian sense J The final sentence of Meckinnon Mackenzie T s letter is remarkable in view of the fact that the B.I. have been quite unable to deal adequately with demands for passages to India for the last four months at least, as we all v|ell know to our cost. Who actually was responsible for the accusation of 'soliciting' for passages levelled against Andrew Weir as agents for Isbrandtsen Moller is not clear, but presumably it was Maekiimon Mackenzie, ^tobay. Anyway, apart from the inaccuracy of any such Btatem&nt and^the harm it might do to Andrew Weir vis-a-vis their principals, it all smacks altogether too much of the most outrageous kind of dog in the manger behaviour and the worst evils of monopoly in the face of situation where all possible shipping facilities are urgently required and a spirit of co operation is essential. I feel that in be Gsury’s phrase it would appear to 'merit Government intemention'. Yours ever, (SIGNED) WGLSTAN WELD-FORESTER. ENCLOSURE Exp/13. * Steamer Department, Air Mail. physicalDescription.extent: The correspondence is arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the volume.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located at the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the British Consul at Basra, HM Ambassador to Iraq, and the Minister of Shipping, regarding the monopoly over shipping in the Persian Gulf held by the British India Steam Navigation Company Limited, and the consequent restrictive effects on other shipping lines and on passenger movement.Further correspondence between HM Representative at Jedda, the Government of India, External Affairs Department, and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, relates to the reduction in shipping services in the Persian Gulf after the requisition of steamers.
